Title(s): ‘That now is hay þat sumtyme was grasse’
_description: ?John Lydgate, ‘That now is hay þat sumtyme was grasse’, possibly by Lydgate — seventeen eight-line stanzas (ababbcbc), including envoy, with this refrain

BodRawC86.First Lines:
Ther is full lytel sicurnessehere in this worlde but
                    transmutacioun…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…Oute of þat place maye be no fallTher is no hey but all
                    fressh grasse
BodRawC86.Note:
Nine stanzas only, but scribe considered finished, wrote
                    ‘ffinis’ (f. 142)

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
Ther is full lytell sikerneshere in this worlde but
                    transmutacion…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…owt of that place may be no fallther is no heye but all fresh
                    grase
BLAdd29729.Note:
Preceded by a note (f. 127v) by scribe (John Stow):
                    ‘here begyneth a balade whych Iohn lydgate the monke of bery wrote made at
                    þe commaundement of þe quene kateryn as in here sportes she wallkyd by
                    the medowes that were late mowen in the monthe of Iulii’.
BLAdd29729.Attributed Author:
Iohn lydgate (f. 127v); Explicit lidgat (f. 129v);
                    finis qod lydgat of bery (f. 129v)
BLAdd29729.Editions:
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 809-13.
